results.title: L'idiot = the Idiot
results.brief_description:
Russian prince Muichkine returns to St. Petersburg after a stay in a Swiss mental hospital. Blissfully unaware of the greater social problems of his country, the prince believes that love and goodness reign supreme around him. He becomes betrothed to an innocent young girl while trying to save a less-innocent woman from her downfall. Jealousy and his own naivete conjoin to bring about an unimaginable tragedy. ‘L’idiot’ was remade in Japan by Akira Kurosawa (1951) and in Russia by Ivan Pyriev (1958).

Credits: Producer, Sacha Gordine ; director, Georges Lampin ; writers, Charles Spaak, Georges Raewsky ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, Maurice Thiriet, V. de Butzow.
Cast: Gerard Philipe, Edwige Feuillere, Lucien Coedel, Nathalie Nattier, Marguerite Moreno, Jean Debucourt, Sylvie.

results.title: L'homme Qui Ment = the Man Who Lies
results.creator_credit: Alain Robbe-Grillet, Maurice Urbain and Samy Halfon
results.brief_description:
Boris Varissa arrives in a small Central European village, used as a haven by local Resitance fighters. He sweet talks his way into the good graces of a family in mourning after the deeath of their son Jean, a Resistance fighter. This avant garde feature leaves the viewer to decide if Boris is telling the truth or covering up for his deeds leading to the death of the heroic Resistance fighter. Awards: Berlin International Film Festival (1968): Best Male Performance for Jean-Louis Trintignant.

Credits: Producers, Maurice Urbain, Samy Halfon ; director, Alain Robbe-Grillet ; writer, Alain Robbe-Grillet ; photography, Igor Luther ; music, Michel Fano ; editor, Bob Wade.
Cast: Jean-Louis Trintignant, Sylvie Breal, Dominique Prado, Ivan Mistrik, Sylvia Turbova, Catherine Robbe-Grillet, Zuzana Kocurikova, Jozef Kroner, Julius Vasek.

results.title: L'homme a la Pipe = Man with the Pipe
results.brief_description:
Documentary on 19th century French painter, Gustave Courbet.

Credits: Director, Roger Leenhardt ; photography, Georges Lendi ; music, Jean Wiener.

results.title: L'europe de L'an Mil = Europe in Year 1000
results.brief_description:
Europe in year 1000 is a wild and hungry world. Fields with poor yield are cultivated by slave labour, toiling in exchange for the protection of a local noble man. This period of history is still dominated by the figure of Charlemagne, emperor and divinity, intermediary bewteen heaven and earth, the visible and the invisible. The Palatine Chapel in Aachen (Germany), an octogonal building modelled on a Byzantine church, was to be his final resting place in 814. It remains a potent symbol of the wealth and power of the Carolingian dynasty. The influence of Byzantine art in Roman imperial art is also illustrated with the example of San Pedro de Roda (Spain). Other main works profiled in this first episode include: Tournus (Burgundy), the Bayeux tapestry, monastries of Reichenau, Echternach, Bamberg, Hildesheim and Liege.

Credits: Director, Roland Darbois ; writers, Roger Stephane, Roland Darbois, photography, Roland Dantigny.
Cast: Narrated by Georges Duby.

results.title: L'etoile du Nord = the North Star
results.creator_credit: Pierre Granier-Deferre and WDR La Sept Cinema
results.brief_description:
After years of aimlessly wandering around Northern Africa, Edouard Binet is sailing back to Europe. On board, he encounters the beautiful Sylvie and introduces her to Nemrod, a successful merchant, who is carrying a valuable jewel. After disembarking, Edouard accepts Sylvie’s offer to stay at her mother’s pension in Belgium. At the pension, Edouard’s charm endears him to Sylvie’s aging, lonely mother, Madame Baron. The stories of his fabulous adventures do much to ease her ennui. When they read in the papers that Nemrod has been murdered during a train trip to Paris and his valuable gem stolen, Sylvie begins to suspect that Edouard may have had something to do with Nemrod’s death. Awards: French Academy of Cinema: Best Supporting Actress: Fanny Cottencon; Best Writing - Adaptation: Jean Aurenche, Pierre Granier-Deferre, Michel Grisolia.

Credits: Producer, Alain Sarde ; director, Pierre Granier-Deferre ; writers, Pierre Granier-Deferre, Jean Aurenche, Michel Grisolia ; photography, Pierre-William Glenn ; music, Philippe Sarde.
Cast: Simone Signoret, Philippe Noiret, Fanny Cottencon, Julie Jezequel, Jean Rougerie.

results.title: L'eternel Evade = the Elusive Prisoner
results.brief_description:
Inspector Flambart is escorting a chain of convicts taking Vidocq back to the prison for the fourth time. Vidocq and his two accomplices manage to break away from the chain gang. Flambart immediadelity launches the chase to re-capture them, but Vidocq has found a safe haven with a most welcoming milkmaid.

Credits: Producer, Etienne Laroche ; director, Marcel Bluwal ; writer, Georges Neveux ; photography, Maurice Damien ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernard Noel, Alain Mottet, Genevieve Fontanel, Jacques Seiler, Mario David.

results.title: L'aventure de la Voile (Ep.3)
results.brief_description:
In this episode we learn about the gallows that were used as war machines well into the 17th century. This episode also covers the famous battle that oppsed Sr francis Drake to the Invincible Armada of the King of Spain. This episode also announces the changes heralded by the arrival of steam engines aboard commercial ships.

Credits: Directors, writers, Daniel Costelle, Jean-Marc Leblon ; photography, Jean-Claude Larrieu, Roland Bernard ; technical adviser, Michel Mollat.

results.title: L'auberge de la Mer Tranquille = the Inn of the Quiet Mother
results.brief_description:
Annette and Vidocq are enjoying a moment of rest at the Inn of the Quiet Mother. But their peace is disrupted by the arrival of a chain gang. The captain of the chain is Vidocq’s old ennemy, capitaine Thierry. Things take a turn for the worse when a convict recognises Vidocq.

Credits: Producer, Etienne Laroche ; director, Marcel Bluwal ; writer, Georges Neveux ; photography, Maurice Damien ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernard Noel, Alain Mottet, Genevieve Fontanel, Jacques Alric, Sacha Briquet, Marcel Charvet, Alain Janey, Dominique Zardi.

results.title: L'atalante [study extract]
results.brief_description: An extract from the last film directed by Jean Vigo, which tells the story of a young skipper of a barge who takes on board his newly-wed country girl, and their slow trip up the Seine towards Paris. The film relates their early love, disillusion, separation and final reconciliation. This extract deals with their separation. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: L'assassin Habite Au 21 = the Killer Is at No. 21
results.brief_description:
A murder takes place at a boarding house full of eccentrics, each one a likely suspect. Clouzot, whose films are generally dark in character, made his feature debut with this delightful comedy-thriller of ‘The Thin Man’ type. The films is not one of these intimidating masterpieces that mark the history of [French] cinema. It is an unpretentious and entertaining piece, solidly built around 2 main centers of interest: the sarcastic and spicy exploration of a boarding house and the colourful fauna living inside it”. Reference: Le Nouvel Observateur, 3 April 1987. German censorship had all the scenes featuring Linz’s interrogation cut out of the film because they were judged too violent. Clouzot had asked the actors playing the police not to fake the action and actor Noel Roquevert who plays Linz finished the scene with a swollen face.

Credits: Director, Henri-Georges Clouzot ; writer, Henri-Georges Clouzot ; photography, Armand Thirard ; music, Maurice Yvain.
Cast: Pierre Fresnay, Suzy Delair, Pierre Larquey, Noel Roquevert, Jean Tissier, Louis Florencie, Raymond Bussieres, Odette Talazac, Marc Natol, Huguette Vivier.
